column2: #Combine all datasets you want to visualize into a single data frame. This data frame should have one #column with all the data values and another column indicating the source dataset or category for each #value.

#Use the ggplot() function to initiate the plot. Define which column of the data frame represents the #data values and which one represents the categories. This is typically done using the aes() function.

#For each dataset or category you want to visualize, add a geom_histogram() layer to the plot. Use the #data=subset(df, category=="your_category_name") argument to specify which subset of the data to use #for each histogram.
#To make sure the histograms are distinguishable when overlaid, adjust their transparency with the alpha argument (e.g., alpha=0.5).
geom_vline(aes(xintercept=mar_mean), color="green4", linetype="dashed", size=1, show.legend=TRUE, label="Mean Married") +
geom_vline(aes(xintercept=mar_median), color="green4", linetype="solid", size=1, show.legend=TRUE, label="Mean Married") +
geom_vline(aes(xintercept=unmar_mean), color="red", linetype="dashed", size=1, show.legend=TRUE, label="Mean Unmarried") +
geom_vline(aes(xintercept=unmar_median), color="red", linetype="solid", size=1, show.legend=TRUE, label="Mean Unmarried") +
labs(title = "Histograms by Marital Status with Mean and Median", x = "BMI Value", y = "Count")
